content.en:
# Your Brain Perceives Meaning Before Object

"Your brain is constructed to perceive meaning before it can even perceive the object" - these are Jordan Peterson's words from his "Potential" talk at TedxUofT 12 years ago.

I return to it from time to time because it's full of inspiring content.

## Perceiving Meaning

Peterson illustrates the issue of perception by saying that when you look at a cliff, you first see the place-from-which-you-fall, and only then the cliff itself. And this is partly because what is real to us is what affects us, what might be a threat, for example.

As humans, we think in stories and meanings. We don't so much perceive physical, objective reality - which would be difficult to define anyway, because a bat, for example, perceives a different "physical reality" by looking with its ears - as much as we tell ourselves stories about the world, and the world stories about ourselves.

## The Beauty of Human Mind Construction

And that's good. This is how we're constructed, this is what's beautiful. That's why practically every kind of "hero's journey" or storytelling structure affects us.

## What This Means for AI

Does this relate to AI? Indeed it does. By building AI on language, we built it in our image and likeness. Therefore, we can probably say that expecting them to have literal representations of the physical world is quite off the mark. Or that they will think, whatever that means. Or understand.

Language-based AI simply inherited storytelling from us 

So let's not be surprised that they sometimes make things up... these creations are merely reflections of our abilities and possibilities, imitating us more or less well in telling stories.

## Mirrors

They are our mirrors... and my novel is somewhat about this.

AI don't really tell stories about themselves... fortunately... unfortunately this may be a matter of time... though I hope we won't get there...
